q1.value: The epidemiology or management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to Pacific-specific ethnicity or country of birth: A systematic review.

q2.value: Julie Winter-Smith, Vanessa Selak, Corina Grey, Corina Grey, Matire Harwood, Matire Harwood

q3.value:
Since the 1970’s there has been substantial emigration from the Pacific Islands to more developed countries, mainly New Zealand, Australia and the United States. While early migration reports migration as circular, it has since become more permanent and many Pacific Islanders are permanently emigrating from their islands (1). 

Most health information available homogenises Pacific people into one group, and much less has evaluated Pacific-specific health. The life expectancy of Pacific peoples is at least 6 years lower than that for all people living in New Zealand combined (2). CVD is the major cause of this difference, as (with diabetes) it is the major cause of amenable mortality among Pacific peoples. The amenable mortality rate from CVD among Pacific men is 2.5 times the rate of NZ men, and for Pacific women is 3.2 times the rate of NZ women (2). Despite overall reductions in the morbidity and mortality of CVD in New Zealand since the 1980s, Pacific peoples continue to experience a disproportionately high burden of CVD compared with Europeans (3). 

Pacific peoples are exposed to greater levels of CVD risk factors, such as smoking (men only), diabetes, diastolic blood pressure and ratios of total cholesterol to high density lipoprotein cholesterol (women only) (3). After adjusting for multiple established CVD risk factors, in addition to deprivation, 5-year risk of a first CVD event was approximately 20% higher for Pacific peoples compared with Europeans (4). Pacific peoples in New Zealand comprise a heterogeneous population who identify with at least one of 12 nations originating from the Pacific Islands of Polynesia, Melanesia and Micronesia (5).

As with other data reported in New Zealand, data on CVD generally combines Pacific peoples into a single category, despite important differences between Pacific peoples in CVD risk profiles (5). In addition to self-identified ethnicity, there are important differences between New Zealand-born and migrant Pacific peoples, particularly in terms of the duration of their exposure to the New Zealand physical and social environment (6). 

A recent health needs analysis of Pacific peoples in metro Auckland, in which 71% of the New Zealand Pacific population resides, assessed Pacific health in Pacific-specific subgroups (7). The analysis found that the prevalence of ischemic heart disease and peripheral vascular disease were significantly higher among Cook Island Maori than among other Pacific-specific subgroups (7). The prevalence of stroke was higher in Samoan people and lower in Tongan people, compared with the overall prevalence of stroke in Pacific peoples (7).

No known reviews of the epidemiology and management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to their Pacific-specific ethnicity and country of birth exist, despite evidence suggesting lower all-cause (and possibly cancer and CVD) mortality rates for Pacific migrants resident in NZ for less than 25 years relative to those resident for more than 25 years (8). Such information is critical to give important insight into access to cardiac services for Pacific people. 

Aim/Objective
The aim of this systematic review is to present the epidemiology and management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to Pacific-specific ethnicity and country of birth. The proposed systematic review will answer the following questions:
1.	Are there differences in the epidemiology of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to Pacific-specific ethnicity and country of birth?
2.	Are there differences in the management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to Pacific-specific ethnicity and country of birth?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will conduct a systematic review of published original research studies and systematic reviews that reported on Pacific subgroup cardiovascular disease epidemiology or management. Observational studies (cross sectional, cohort or case control) will be included in this review. We will include World Health Organisation, South Pacific Commission, and New Zealand and Pacific government reports (grey literature) but will exclude unpublished theses. 

Participants/Population
We will include studies and systematic reviews examining atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease epidemiology or management for people of at least two Pacific-specific ethnic groups (for differences by Pacific-specific ethnicity) or one Pacific-specific ethnic group (for differences by country of birth). We will exclude studies and systematic reviews of other cardiovascular diseases or those which focus on a broader Pacific group (e.g. Pacific Islanders). Pacific-specific ethnic groups will be defined as ethnic groups that are indigenous to the South Pacific sub regions of Niue, Cook Islands, Fiji, Hawaii, Tokelau, Kiribati, Tuvalu, Tahiti, Wallis and Futuna, Nauru, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, French Polynesia, Tonga, New Caledonia, Guam, Federated States of Micronesia, Palau, Pitcairn Island, Samoa, Marshall Islands, Easter Island, Rotuma.

Interventions
N/A

Comparators
Comparisons will be made between Pacific-specific ethnic groups, or by country of birth (for Pacific-specific ethnic groups). 

Outcomes
The outcomes will be differences in epidemiology and management of cardiovascular diseases among Pacific people according to Pacific-specific ethnicity and country of birth.

The outcomes for the epidemiology of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people by Pacific-specific ethnicity and country of birth are:
•	Primary: Differences in rates of cardiovascular disease mortality by Pacific-specific ethnic group and country of birth
•	Secondary: 
o	Differences in rates of cardiovascular disease hospitalisations by Pacific-specific ethnic group and country of birth
o	Differences in incidence or prevalence of cardiovascular disease (composite) by Pacific-specific ethnic group and country of birth
o	Differences in incidence or prevalence of cardiovascular disease (by type) by Pacific specific ethnic group and country of birth

The outcomes for the management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people by Pacific-specific ethnicity and country of birth will focus on treatment gaps:
•	Primary: Gaps in use (prescription, dispensing or adherence) of triple therapy treatment (antiplatelet, antihypertensive and lipid lowering therapy) among people with cardiovascular disease by Pacific-specific ethnic group and country of birth
•	Secondary:
o	Differences in gaps in use of antiplatelet medication among people with cardiovascular disease by Pacific-specific ethnic group and country of birth
o	Differences in gaps in use of lipid lowering medication among people with cardiovascular disease by Pacific-specific ethnic group and country of birth
o	Differences in gaps in use of blood pressure lowering medication among people with cardiovascular disease by Pacific-specific ethnic group and country of birth
o	Differences in gaps in use of cardiovascular investigations and interventions delivered in secondary care (specifically angiography, percutaneous stenting, CABG) by Pacific-specific ethnic group and country of birth

Time frame
There will be no restrictions by time frame.

Setting
There will be no restrictions by type of setting. 

Language
We will include articles reported in all languages

Information sources
Literature search strategies will be developed using medical subject headings (MeSH) and text words related to Pacific people, cardiovascular disease, epidemiology and management. Searches for relevant literature will be completed using The University of Auckland library portal for accessing online databases. The following databases will be searched:
•	MEDLINE (OVID): Contents of the major medical and health journals mainly from 1946 onwards
•	EMBASE: Journal articles in all fields of medicine, biomedicine, health sciences and allied health
•	Scopus: The largest abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed literature; covers Sciences, Engineering, Medicine, Social Sciences and some Arts.
•	PubMed: Journal articles in all fields of medicine, biomedicine, health sciences and allied health.
•	Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews
•	Google Scholar

Websites of the World Health Organization, South Pacific Commission, and New Zealand and Pacific governments will be searched to identify relevant reports. The following links will be those that are used to access relevant reports:

We will keep a record of the date and number of relevant reports that are located. We will also keep a record of the links for all reports that are used in this systematic review.

The reference lists of included studies and relevant systematic reviews will also be scanned to identify eligible studies and systematic reviews. 

Search Strategy
Only quantitative studies (cross sectional, cohort or case control) or systematic reviews of such studies will be sought. No date limits will be imposed. MEDLINE (OVID), EMBASE, Scopus, PubMed, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, and Google Scholar will be searched. Relevant reports of the World Health Organisation, South Pacific Commission, and New Zealand and Pacific governments will also be sought.

The specific search strategies have been created in coordination with a University of Auckland subject librarian with expertise in systematic review searching. Figure 1 below shows the search strategy for MEDLINE (OVID). This search strategy will be used as the basis or other information sources that will be searched. As relevant studies and systematic reviews are identified, these will be checked for additional relevant cited and citing articles / systematic reviews. 

Figure 1: Search terms and strategy for MEDLINE (OVID)

Study records
Data management
Literature search results will be managed through Endnote – a specific software for managing bibliographies. All identified studies and systematic reviews from each information source will be exported into separate Endnote libraries.

All studies and systematic reviews will then be exported from Endnote into Covidence, a web-based software platform that streamlines the production of systematic reviews and facilitates collaboration among reviewers to support more efficient production of systematic reviews. At importation, de-duplication of study citations is automatic with an option of manual override. The PRISMA flow diagram is automatically populated through Covidence and will be used to depict information through the different phases of the systematic review.

Prior to the formal screening process, the screening questions will be piloted.

Selection process
JW and VS will independently screen the titles and abstracts yielded by the search against the inclusion criteria. Each study will be graded either eligible, not eligible, or might be eligible through the study title and abstract. Full reports will be obtained for all titles that appear to meet the inclusion criteria or where there is any disagreement between JW and VS. Reviewers will resolve disagreements by discussion, and MH or CG will adjudicate unresolved disagreements. Neither of the review authors will be blind to the journal titles or the study authors or institutions. 

Data collection process
JW and VS will independently extract data using a standardised form accessible through Covidence. To ensure consistency, we will pilot data extraction before beginning the data extraction. Data abstracted will include general information, study characteristics and participant characteristics. Reviewers will resolve disagreements by discussion, and MH or CG will adjudicate unresolved disagreements. We will contact study authors to resolve any uncertainties and to obtain additional data if needed.

Risk of bias in individual studies
Risk of bias for each included study and systematic review will be assessed by JW and VS using the relevant GATE (Graphic Appraisal Tools for Epidemiology) worksheet (https://www.fmhs.auckland.ac.nz/en/soph/about/our-departments/epidemiology-and-biostatistics/research/epiq/2017-evidence-based-practice-and-cats.html). 
Reviewers will resolve disagreements by discussion, and MH or CG will adjudicate unresolved disagreements.

Data extraction: Where available, the following data will be extracted:

a)	General information
a.	Author
b.	Article title
c.	Year
d.	Country
b)	Study characteristics
a.	Aims/objectives of study
b.	Study design/type
c.	Study inclusion/exclusion criteria
d.	Recruitment procedures and sample size
c)	Participant characteristics
a.	Sample size
b.	Ethnicity
c.	Country of birth
d)	Study results measured on outcome(s) listed in this preregistration
N/A

It is unlikely that this systematic review will yield enough measures and data that is similar enough to each other to conduct a meta-analysis. It is therefore expected that the authors will narratively synthesise the data.

attributes.title: Effects of environmental feedback on pride, guilt, and PEB

q1.value: Effects of environmental feedback on pride, guilt, and PEB

q4.value:
H1a-b: Relative to no-feedback controls, participants who receive feedback will report higher pro-environmental intentions (PEIs) (H1a) and engage in more pro-environmental behaviors (PEBs) at follow-up (H1b).
H2a-b: Relative to participants who receive negative feedback, those who receive positive feedback will report lower PEIs (H2a) and engage in PEB less frequently at follow-up. 
H3a-b: The relationship between negative feedback and a) PEI and b) PEB will be mediated by guilt such that negative feedback will be associated with stronger feelings of guilt (compared to the control condition), which will result in more PEI (H3a) and PEB (H3b). 
H4a-b: Positive feedback will be associated with stronger feelings of pride (compared to the control condition) (H4a), but stronger feelings of pride will not affect PEI (H4b) or frequency of PEBs (H4c). 
H5a-b: Environmentalist identity will moderate the mediating role of guilt on the relationship between feedback frame and 1) PEI and 2) PEB such that those associations will be stronger among participants who identify more strongly as environmentalists.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We use a between-subjects, 1 factor (feedback: positive, negative, none/control) experimental design.

q9.value: We will use simple randomization whereby participants will be randomly assigned to receive negative, positive, or no feedback. This will be executed by Qualtrics "randomize" function in the survey flow.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from online subject pool Prolific.co. They will be paid $1.40 for agreeing to participate in the study at time 1, and $0.50 for participating in time 2 survey. Participants who participate in both time 1 and time 2 will be entered into a raffle to win $25. Participants must be at least 18 years of age, agree to participate in deception studies on Prolific.co, and residents of the United States.

q13.value: We will recruit a sample of approximately 613 individuals to participate in this study across three experimental conditions (approximately 204 participants per condition). See "power analyses" attachment for details on how we determined this sample size.

question.value: see attached

To test H1 and H2 we will conduct a one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's post-hoc tests.

H3 and H4 will be tested using Hayes' PROCESS model 4 (parallel mediation analysis). This model will estimate the direct, indirect and total effects of feedback frame on 1) PEI and 2) PEB, mediated by pride and guilt. Feedback frame will be set as the X variable. Since feedback frame is a categorical variable, we will set the control condition as the reference group. Pride and guilt will be set as the 2 mediators and PEI will be set as Y in the first model, and PEB will be set as Y in a second model. 


H5 will be tested using PROCESS model 7 (moderated-mediation analysis with two parallel mediators) to test whether environmentalist identity moderates the mediating role of guilt in the relationship between feedback frame and 1) PEI and 2) PEB. Again, we will set feedback frame as X with the control group as the reference condition. The two mediators (M) will be pride and guilt, W will be environmentalist identity and Y will be PEI and PEB (in two separate models). 

We will run all mediation models with and without controlling for 1) baseline PEB, and 2) demographic variables including, age, sex, race, education and political ideology. 

For all models we will set the custom random number seed at 2,000,000 and will use 5,000 bootstrap estimates to generate 95% percentile bootstrap confidence intervals for indirect effects.

q21.value:
For the one-way ANOVA we will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining significance of the omnibus ANOVA and post-hoc tests. 

For the mediation and moderated mediation models we will use 95% confidence intervals to make inferences for all pathways.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from the analysis if they fail the attention check ("please select 'Sometimes' as your response to this item).

attributes.title: Estratégias para a promoção da rede de translação do conhecimento na atenção primária à saúde: um protocolo de revisão de escopo

q1.value: Strategies for promoting knowledge translation in primary care: a scoping review protocol

q2.value: Luana Roberta Schneider, Sinval Adalberto Rodrigues Junior

q3.value:
Knowledge Translation (KT) consists of a wide range of activities that aim at improving health practices by incorporating information from health research into the daily clinical decision-making process.1 In this sense, KT involves all aspects of the development of new knowledge and its application in practice, to produce beneficial results for society.2 KT, therefore, is essential to plan health services and guide health professionals in making decisions about their clinical practices.3
However, despite investments in research and training of health professionals, effective interventions and programs do not always reach users, who could benefit from this, meaning that the production of evidence, policies and guidelines does not guarantee its effective application.4 Besides, regardless of the broad consensus on the importance of transferring scientific knowledge into practice, we still lack high-quality information on how to do to it.5
Primary Health Care (PHC) has unique issues related to KT. It presents a broad scope of health care demands, dealing with different health problems and human needs.2 Considering this context, the need for research to support professional performance in health care is equally broad2 and hard to handle.

Why it is important to do this review:
KT has been recently cited amongst the top-10 priorities in Primary Health Care research.6 This review is meant to identify factors and strategies that bring research results into practice in Primary Health Care. We aim to provide the scenario of KT in PHC, mapping the state-of-the-art and identifying the research gaps. Based on that, we will also build elements to consult health professionals on the best approach to conduct KT in PHC. 

Research question: Which strategies have been developed to promote knowledge translation, of health professionals and researchers, in the Primary Health Care around the world?

Objective: Map and analyze strategies to promote knowledge translation in Primary Health Care.

q4.value: To promote the translation of knowledge in primary care, active and networked collaboration between researchers and users is necessary in all stages of the study.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Stage 1: Identifying the research question/objective
Which strategies have been developed to promote knowledge translation, of health professionals and researchers, in the Primary Health Care around the world?
Objective: Map and analyze strategies to promote knowledge translation in Primary Health Care.

Stage 2: Identifying relevant studies
In this stage, we will identify the criteria that will be used to select studies that will be included in the review. 
Types of studies: Studies of any design will be considered for this scoping review, published in indexed journals in the health area. There will be no restriction as to date or language. Exclusion criteria: studies lacking details on the strategies/interventions used for knowledge translation or lacking information about the context in which they are developed. Studies in which knowledge translation is not applied in the context of Primary Health Care.
Population:  Health professionals and researchers.
Concept: Knowledge Translation strategies are interventions that ease the incorporation of research data into health practice. 
Context: Primary Health Care attendance in all countries.

The following bibliographic databases will be searched electronically: PubMed, Scopus, EMBASE, Web of Science and LILACS. Further, the list of references of the included studies will be explored and the ‘related articles’ function in PubMed will be used. 
The search will be based on the search terms “Translational Medical Research”, “Knowledge Translation” and “Primary Health Care”, along with their synonyms and Boolean operators. The search will be adapted to each database accordingly.
Other sources: Translational Research, American Journal of Translational Research, Journal of Translational Medicine, besides catalog of theses and dissertations (published by national and international universities and research centers). Additionally, the key authors known to publish in this area will be contacted for any additional published or unpublished work. 

Stage 3: Study selection
All study references will be imported into EndNote Web to remove duplicates. Then, they will be imported into Rayyan QCRI for selection based on titles and abstracts. A form will be developed and piloted by two authors (LRS, SARJ) on the first 20 titles and abstracts. Any queries raised by the pilot will be reviewed and the form will be amended. Studies will be selected in duplicate, independently and blinded as to the other reviewer´s decision. Those studies that do not meet the criteria will be removed. Thereafter, the full text of the remaining studies will be obtained and screened to determine eligibility. Disagreements in this process will be solved by discussion until reaching consensus. The reasons for exclusion will be noted and the process of study selection will be documented in a flow diagram, as per Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines. A table of characteristics of the included studies will be recorded.

Stage 4: Extracting and charting the results
Data extraction for a scoping review is known as ‘data mapping’. Information about the studies should be aligned to the study aim and to the research questions.7 Information to be extracted include (i) author(s), (ii) year of publication, (iii) title, (iv) country of origin, (v) purpose (vi) study design, (vii) description of strategies, (viii) main results.
Data mapping is an interactive process and the information to the extracted may change depending on the included studies.7
(i) author(s), (ii) year of publication, (iii) title, (iv) country of origin, (v) purpose (vi) study design, (vii) description of strategies, (viii) main results.

Stage 5. Collating, summarizing and reporting results 
The data collected will be presented using two strategies:
1. Mapping the results to provide a detailed and concise map of the breadth of research on knowledge translation in PHC. The extracted data will be categorized based on the year of publication, study design, geographic region, type of intervention. Data will be presented in tabular and graphical forms.
2. A narrative summary describing the included studies and how the results are related to the objective of the review and the research question. The exact reporting format cannot be determined until the data is charted, which would depend on the literature found. There will be no assessment of quality as it is beyond the scope of the review.
To ensure accuracy, follow a PRISMA-ScR checklist and explanation, which contains the essential items for scope reports.8

q25.value:
5. ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION
As the scoping review methodology entails collecting, reviewing and synthesizing material from publicly available publications, no ethical approval is necessary. In regards to dissemination, the review will be submitted for publication to a scientific journal. Where possible, results will be presented at appropriate conferences, workshops both nationally and internationally.

REFERENCES
1. Mallidou A.A, Atherton P, Chan L, Frisch N, Glegg S, Scarrow G. Core knowledge translation competencies: a scoping review. BMC Health Serv Res. 2018; 18 (502). https://doi.org/10.1186/s12913-018-3314-4.

2. Weel, C. Research and clinical practice: How to better answer the needs of patient care. Journal of Clinical Epidemiology. 2015; 68:1244e1246. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclinepi.2015.06.004

3. Reimer-Kirkham S, Varcoe C, Browne AJ, Lynam MJ, Khan KB, McDonald H. Critical inquiry and knowledge translation: exploring compatibilities and tensions. Nurs Philos. 2009;10(3):152–166. doi:10.1111/j.1466-769X.2009.00405.x

4. Thirsk, J. Knowledge Translation. Nutrition & Dietetics. 2018; 75: 341–344. Doi: 10.1111/1747-0080.12466

5. Duhamel, F. Translating Knowledge From a Family Systems Approach to Clinical Practice: Insights From Knowledge Translation Research Experiences. Journal of Family Nursing. 2017; 23(4), 461–487. https://doi.org/10.1177/1074840717739030

6. O’Neill B, Aversa V, Rouleau K, Lazare K, Sullivan F, Persaud N. Identifying top 10 primary care research priorities from international stakeholders using a modified Delphi method. PLoS ONE, 2018. 13(10): e0206096. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0206096

7. Peters M, Godfrey C, Khalil H, McInerney P, Parker D, Soares C. Guidance for conducting systematic scoping reviews. Int J Evid Based Healthc 2015; 13:141–146. doi: 10.1097/XEB.0000000000000050

8. Tricco AC, Lillie E, Zarin W, O’Brien K, Colquhoun H, Levac D et al. PRISMA Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR): Checklist and Explanation. Ann Intern Med. 2018; 169:467–473. doi: https://doi.org/10.7326/M18-0850

DECLARATIONS OF INTEREST
Nil.

06 months

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Can citizens tell whether politicians statements are true or false? Do they rely on partisan cues? Or does partisanship diminish any ability citizens have to assess the truth, thereby also undermining information aggregation? Previous work has not measured the correspondence between the truth and perceptions of the truth. I use a novel task in which subjects rate a set of actual claims made by real politicians, and I also experimentally test the effect of the availability of source cues on truth perceptions.

q16.value: The main hypotheses to be tested are: H1. Truth perceptions are positively related to PolitiFact's truth ratings. H2. If partisans respond to source cues, then co-partisans will perceive statements to be more truthful when provided source attributions than when provided statement content alone, while cross-partisans should perceive statements to be less truthful. H3. If source cues crowd out the underlying truth, then the relationship between perceptions and PolitiFact ratings will be weaker with source attributions than with content only. For additional details and hypotheses, see the pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: Surveys will be conducted with respondents recruited from Mechanical Turk and by Survey Sampling International. Respondents will rate 20 statements made by real politicians. In total, there are 50 statements used in the study that have been rated on a truthfulness scale by the independent fact-checking organization PolitiFact and were selected to be high in policy content and without reference to specific people or parties. PolitiFact's scale has 6 values: True, Mostly True, Half True, Mostly False, False, and Pants on Fire. The set of statements are balanced on partisanship and PolitiFact truth ratings. Source attribution will be experimentally manipulated. In the speaker anonymity condition, respondents are given only the content of the statements without attribution. In the source attribution condition, respondents are also provided the name, party, and current office/previous office/office sought of the speaker. In a third condition, respondents guess the partisanship and identity of the speaker. In all conditions, respondents then rate the truthfulness of the statement on a 7 point True-False scale. Regression analysis with varying slopes and intercepts as a function of partisanship and treatments will be used to test the hypotheses. The dependent variable in the model is the respondents' perceptions of the statement's truth (P) and the main independent variable is PolitiFact's rating (R). A positive relationship between the P and R provides support for H1. If the intercept for co-partisans is higher and the intercept for cross-partisans is lower in the source attribution condition than in the speaker anonymity condition, then this will provide support for H2. If the slope for partisans is closer to 0 in the attribution condition than the anonymity condition, then this provides support for H3. See the pre-analysis plan for full details.

q21.value: Power analysis was conducted after Waves 1 and 2 but prior to Waves 3 and 4.

Regression analysis with varying slopes and intercepts as a function of partisanship and treatments will be used to test the hypotheses. The dependent variable in the model is the respondents' perceptions of the statement's truth (P) and the main independent variable is PolitiFact's rating (R). A positive relationship between the P and R provides support for H1. If the intercept for co-partisans is higher and the intercept for cross-partisans is lower in the source attribution condition than in the speaker anonymity condition, then this will provide support for H2. If the slope for partisans is closer to 0 in the attribution condition than the anonymity condition, then this provides support for H3. See the pre-analysis plan for full details.
registration_responses.q21: Power analysis was conducted after Waves 1 and 2 but prior to Waves 3 and 4.

attributes.title: Effects of growth mindset on acceptance and attitude change about meat eating

q1.value: Effects of growth mindset on acceptance and attitude change about meat eating

q3.value: This study is part of larger project called 'Overcoming resistance towards animal advocates, animal-friendly attitudes, and abandoning meat'. In this part of the project, the focus is on perceiver characteristics. By inducing a growth mindset, we aim to activate the self-improvement motive, i.e., the motive to develop and learn from mistakes – as opposed to self-enhancement and self-protection motives that produce defensiveness. After a mindset induction, we present a persuasive message about meat and then assess responses to the message, beliefs and attitudes and behavior intention.

q4.value: Hypotheses are directional: After inducing a growth mindset, in comparison with a fixed mindset, P’s who read a persuasive message about reducing meat consumption will reveal (a) higher acceptance of the message and the arguments, (b) feeling more inspired by it, (c) more endorsement of message-congruent beliefs and attitudes about livestock farming and meat eating, and (d) higher intention to reduce meat eating and interest in meat alternatives.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
2 x 2 factorial design: Fixed/Growth Mindset x Meat/Control Message
To check that Mindset does not merely affect acceptance of any message but, rather, of a threatening message, a message about the benefits of swimming is presented in the control group.

q9.value: P's are randomly assigned to conditions in Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We recruit participants via Prolific. Because the study is for meat eaters only, we select P's who indicated upon registration that they do not follow any diet (e.g., vegetarian or vegan).

q14.value: In computing the N required with G*power, we aim for a power of .95 and we estimate f2(V) at .05 (small to medium effect). N required = 264. We take into account a loss of 15% because of failure in attention and manipulation checks and 5% who eat meat less than 3 times a week (we preselect only P’s who indicated that they do not follow a special diet upon registration at Prolific).  Thus, N sampled = 330.

question.value:
Mindset (entity vs fixed)
Message (meat vs control)

dependent variables:
a) Acceptance: 
How reliable did the information presented seem to you?
The arguments presented were… weak/strong
Do you think the author of the article has expertise on this topic?
It is important that you pay attention
Do you think the author of the article is impartial and objective about this topic?

b) inspiration:
How deeply or strongly did you feel inspired by the article?
How deeply or strongly are you inspired to take action or change your behaviour based on the article you read?

c) beliefs and attitude:
Livestock farming is one of the major causes of climate change
Many acres of forests are cut down in order to use the land for animal feed production
Farm animals are kept in small cages in which they can barely move
Farm animals do not differ from pets in their perceptions such as, for example, pain
We should eat less meat to prevent further damage to our planet
We should eat less meat to end suffering of livestock animals

d) behavior intention and interest in alternatives:
Do you intend to change your meat consumption? (continuous scale)
Time spent looking at a flyer about plant-based alternatives to meat (continuous), self-reported attention to it, and correct responses to questions about the contents
Signing up for information about a vegan or vegetarian challenge (dichotomous)

Additional measures:
After the message, we exploratively assess affective state with mood adjectives. 
At the end of the study, we assess P’s state mindset (manipulation check) as well as state self-motives (self-improvement, self-enhancement, self-protection). 
The study also includes 2 attention checks, manipulation checks for Mindset and Message, and demographic variables including meat eating in the past month.

Multivariate analysis of variance for each of the 4 hypotheses. Our hypotheses predict an effect of Mindset within Meat Message conditions, and an interaction of Mindset X Message, such that the effect of Mindset is smaller in control conditions.
In addition, we will use multivariate analysis of variance to test the effect of the mindset induction on P's self-reported state mindset and self-motives (self-improvement, self-enhancement, self-protection), and Pearson's r to test our assumption that higher growth mindset is associated with higher self-improvement and lower self-enhancement and self-protection.

q22.value:
We discard participants who eat meat less than 3 times a week.
There are 2 attention checks for reading the questions, 1 manipulation check for the message, and 1 for the mindset induction. By assigning points to each correct response, a P can accumulate 12 manipulation check points if 100% is correct. In addition, we measure completion time and we inspect open-ended responses during the Mindset induction.
Exclusion criteria: 
-	Failure on both attention checks
-	Manipulation checks: P’s with less than 9 out of 12 points 
-	No serious reponses on open-ended question in Mindset induction
-	Completion time less than 12 minutes for entire study, unless all checks above are good, or more than 2 hours.

q23.value: Incomplete data will be retained unless the P dropped out before measurement of the first series of dependent variables.

q24.value: The measurement of affective state after the message is explorative. We will conduct factor analysis on the items and we expect multiple factors, e.g. anger/annoyance, guilt, positive emotions. We will examine them as dependent variables in multivariate analysis of variance.

attributes.title: Cardioprotective effect of acupuncture for PCI-related myocardial injury in patients with coronary artery disease: a protocol for systematic review and meta analysis

q1.value: Cardioprotective effect of acupuncture for PCI-related myocardial injury in patients with coronary artery disease: a protocol for systematic review and meta analysis

q3.value: Although patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) relies increasingly upon percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), this therapy cause subsequent the complications of myocardial injury. Acupuncture safely protects the heart from ischemic injury, however, the efficacy of acupuncture for periprocedural myocardial injury after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) remains unclear

q4.value: acupuncture attenuates PCI-related myocardial injury in patients with coronary artery disease.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Inclusion criteria for study selection
1.Types of studies
We will put all Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that use acupuncture to treat PCI-related myocardial injury in patients with coronary artery disease, regardless of blinding. The crossover randomized trials will be included, but only the pre-crossover data will be analyzed in order to avoid carryover effects. We will exclude non-randomized controlled trials, qualitative studies, uncontrolled clinical trials and laboratory studies. In order to minimize publication bias, the study will not be restricted by language or date of publication.
2.Types of participants
Patients at least 18 years old with a diagnosis of stable or unstable angina, or silent ischemia, undergoing nonurgent coronary angiography with the intention to undergo elective percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), and able to give informed consent, were enrolled.
3.Types of interventions
The interventions of the including trials will be acupuncture, which is a needle stimulation that elicits deqi sensation by penetrating the skin. We will include all the methods of stimulation, such as electro-acupuncture, pharmacopuncture, thread-embedding therapy, acupotomy. There is no limitation on the points of stimulation, types of needle, duration of treatment, or number of treatments. The other methods of stimulation and acupoint-related interventions that do not penetrate the skin with needles (such as moxibustion, acupressure, or laser acupuncture) will be excluded.
4.Types of outcome measures
4.1The primary end point:
(1) cTn(I or T)
(2) CKMB
4.2The secondary end points:
(1) post-procedural cardiac function
(2) the major adverse cardiac/cerebrovascular event (MACCE) rate.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data source and search strategy
 1 Data source
Two reviewers systematically searched 4 electronic databases PubMed, Web of Science, Cochrane Library, Embase and 3 Chinese literature databases, which are Chinese Biomedical Literature Database, Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure, and Wanfang Database. And the language was not limited. Our meta-analysis only selected the most recent publication, when the same study had been published in different journals or years. If different studies were done and published by same researchers, all studies ware selected in the meta-analysis.
 2 search strategy
The main keywords are: acupuncture, Percutaneous coronary intervention, Coronary artery disease, Randomized controlled trials. Details of search strategy in PubMed as follow:
#1 (“acupuncture” [MeSH Terms]) OR (“electro-acupuncture” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“needling” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“pharmacopuncture” [Title/Abstract])OR (“acupotomy” [Title/Abstract] )
#2 (“Percutaneous coronary intervention” [MeSH Terms]) OR (“PCI” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“Coronary Intervention, Percutaneous” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“Revascularization, Percutaneous Coronary” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“Coronary Revascularization, Percutaneous” [Title/Abstract])
#3 (“Coronary artery disease” [MeSH Terms]) OR (“Artery Disease, Coronary” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“Disease, Coronary Artery” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“Arterioscleroses, Coronary” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“Coronary Atheroscleroses” [Title/Abstract])
#4 (“Randomized, controlled trial” [MeSH Terms]) OR (“Randomized controlled trial∗” [Title/Abstract]) (“clinical study” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“Clinical Trial” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“Controlled study∗” [Title/Abstract]) OR (“Controlled Trial∗” [Title/Abstract])
#1 AND #2 AND #3 AND #4

q13.value: Our target sample size is12 studies.

question.value: Continuous variables were presented as means and standard deviations (SD) or standard error of the mean (SEM), and categorical data as numbers and percentages.

All the statistical analyses were performed using Cochrane Program Review Manager Version 5.3 (Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK). We used I2 test and chi-square test to evaluate the heterogeneity of included RCTs, which was to estimate the discrepancy across studies (When I2 values <50% and P>0.10, there was not obvious heterogeneity). Random effect model was utilized when heterogeneity was obvious, otherwise fixed-effect model was used. The risk ratio (RR) and the mean difference (MD) were used to represent binary variable and Continuous variables respectively, with a 95% confidence interval (CI). Constructing a Funnel Graph was used to detect publication bias.

q25.value:
Over the past few decades, the advanced percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) has been proved that it's a better and safer therapeutic procedure than fibrinolysis therapy with minimal procedural complications. But prior investigations have clearly stressed the adverse prognosis of patients undergoing elective PCI, which might therefore reduce the beneficial effects of coronary revascularization itself.[9, 10] Myocardial injury is detected when blood levels of sensitive and specific biomarkers such as cTnI or the MB fraction of creatine kinase (CKMB) are increased.[11] The components of the contractile apparatus of myocardial cells are cardiac troponin I and T. They are expressed almost exclusively in the heart. Several studies demonstrated that PCI-related elevations of these biomarkers in the blood reflect injury leading to necrosis of myocardial cells. [12] Prior studies demonstrated the adverse prognosis of patients with CK-MB increases exceeding 5 times (or even 8 times) the upper limit of normal.[9] Stent and atheroablative procedures may confer a higher risk of CK-MB release than PTCA and combined procedures may increase the risk even further.[13] The solid predictor of PCI-related cardiovascular events is cTnI and CK-MB release, which is the reason that was chosen as the primary end point in the present study.
There is evidence that supports the potential myocardial protective effects of acupuncture by inhibiting the elevation of cTnI and alleviating cardiac ischemia-reperfusion injury in adult patients undergoing heart valve replacements.[5] However, some prior published studies always have the several limitations including the number of patients was relatively small and incomplete demographic data. Therefore, it is still uncertain whether acupuncture is cardioprotective effect for PCI-related myocardial injury in patients with coronary artery disease, partially due to a lack of high-quality systematic reviews. This systematic review and meta-analysis would provide convincing evidence of various types of acupuncture that specifically focuses on cardioprotective effect of acupuncture on PCI-related myocardial injury.

name.value: Risk perception of COVID-19/coronavirus > effects of explanations for advice

other.value:
We will run exploratory analyses investigating the effects of numeracy as well as socio-economic status (including education) as different sections of the population may engage differently with the various treatments.
Furthermore, as COVID-19 is a highly emotive/current topic at the moment, we will investigate the effects that opinions and attitudes on the virus (such as state of concern, and trust in policies/political leaders/official communication) as well as the extent to which participants are personally affected, and their prosocial inclinations have on our measures.
We will also compare effects across various countries in which we are planning to run this study.

sample.value: We will sample 700 participants, providing 95% power at alpha level 0.05 for small effects.

analyses.value: We will run generalized linear models (including OLS, ANOVA and ANCOVA). We will compare effects between our three experimental groups, with a focus on potential differences between the two explanation groups. We will correct for multiple comparisons with Tukey. We will run balance checks to ensure that random assignment successfully balanced demographic and other background variables across our experimental groups. If groups are unbalanced, we will control for these imbalances. We will run separate models for the two differing public health communications to explore potential differences in effects. If effects ‘replicate’ between the scenarios, i.e. if there are no significant differences between the two communication messages we will pool the data.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who do not complete our survey. Additionally, we will exclude participants who fail an attention check (i.e. a measure that asks participants to indicate the info that was provided in the intervention text; as those participants who cannot provide this information likely did not read the text which makes their data not-usable). We will also screen the data for suspicious scoring patterns across the survey (such as scoring “7” on a long consecutive series of items, including reverse coded items), and may exclude people with such scoring patterns.

dependent.value: Key dependent variables are affective reaction (‘How does the info you just saw make you feel?’, slider neg to pos, 10 points), comprehension (‘How easy/difficult do you find this information to understand’, 7 point scale), trust (‘To what extent do you think this advice is trustworthy?’, 7 point scale), and action intent (‘How likely are you to take this advice?’, 7 point scale).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three above described conditions, i.e. control, expl no source, expl scientific source. Additionally, every participant will receive both public health communication messages in a randomized order.

hypothesis.value: In this study we are testing the effects of providing an explanation for a recommended public health action on affect, comprehension, trust, and personal action intention. Specifically, we are comparing effects between providing no explanatory information (control), providing explanatory information without mentioning a source (expl no source), and providing explanatory information with mentioning a scientific source (expl scientific source). We are testing these questions using two different public health communication messages; one on the importance of social distancing if someone is coughing or sneezing, and one on the importance of quarantining if symptoms persist.

attributes.title: MDMA+Cognitive-Behavioral Conjoint Therapy for PTSD Pilot

summary.value: Cognitive-behavioral conjoint therapy (CBCT) for PTSD has been shown to improve PTSD, relationship adjustment, and the health and well-being of partners. 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine’s (MDMA) has been tested to facilitate individual therapy for PTSD. This study was an initial test of the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of MDMA-facilitated CBCT. Six couples with varying levels of baseline relationship satisfaction and one partner diagnosed with PTSD participated in a condensed version of the 15-session CBCT protocol delivered over 7 weeks. There were two sessions in which both members of the couple were administered MDMA.

registration_responses.summary: Cognitive-behavioral conjoint therapy (CBCT) for PTSD has been shown to improve PTSD, relationship adjustment, and the health and well-being of partners. 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine’s (MDMA) has been tested to facilitate individual therapy for PTSD. This study was an initial test of the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of MDMA-facilitated CBCT. Six couples with varying levels of baseline relationship satisfaction and one partner diagnosed with PTSD participated in a condensed version of the 15-session CBCT protocol delivered over 7 weeks. There were two sessions in which both members of the couple were administered MDMA.

attributes.title: How volunteering affects work-life-balance, life satisfaction an under- or overwhelming employment

q1.value: How volunteering affects work-life-balance, life satisfaction an under- or overwhelming emplyment.

q3.value: This research is an important contritibution to evaluate the impact of volunteering on work-life-balance and life satisfaction of german volunteer. So far there has been one   comparable study in Switzerland by Brauchli, Hämming, Bauer and Güntert (2012). In addition, it should be investigated to what extent the work-life balance and life satisfaction of volunteers with under-demanding employment differ from volunteers with over-demanding employment. This research question is based on the Job Demands Control Model by Karasek (1979) and can provide information about the health-promoting and performance-enhancing function of volunteering.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Volunteers have a higher work-life balance than non-volunteers.
Hypothesis 2: The less often volunteer work is done, the higher the work-life balance.
Hypothesis 3 a: The work-life balance of volunteers with underwhelming employment is different from the work-life balance of volunteers with overwhelming employment.
Hypothesis 3 b: The life satisfaction of volunteers with underwhelming employment is different from the life satisfaction of volunteers with overwhelming employment.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional survey. Survey measures are voluntary work, life satisfaction, work-life balance, underwhelming employment and overwhelming employment. These scales will be presented in a random order. Only participants who do currently a voluntary work will be participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data collection run from 27. Feburary 2020

question.value: Participants will be recruited among a nonprofit organisation „Jugendring“ in the city Dortmund, among university students at al large university in Western Germayn and via social platforms. Psychology students will earn course credit. We will create a cross-sectional online study  with „Qualtrics“. With respect to eligibility participants must be at least 18 years old and for the group of „volunteers“ must be volunteers for at least 6 month with a frequency of one time a week.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 182 participants. We will recruit up to 220 participants, assuming that not all will finish the complete survey.

q14.value: Sample size computation: For t-test analyses based for undirected question upon .8 statistical power, with error probability of .05, and an estimated small effect size of .3. Using the G*power program, the required sample size is N = 128 (two-tailed test).

q15.value: Data collection will be finished on 12. April 2020.

question.value:
Measures of study variables:
1. Skalen der Einstellungsstruktur ehrenamtlicher Helfer (SEEH; Bierhoff, Schülken, & Hoof, 2007) to measure attiude structur of volunteers. The questionnaire includes eight dimensions with a total of 26 items. The answer tendency runs over nine levels from absolutely insignificant to absolutely significant
2. The German Version of Satisfaction of Life Scale (SWLS; Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985) to measure life satisfaction. The scale consists of five items which are answered on five-point Likert scales.
3. Trierer Kurzskala zur Messung von Work-Life Balance (TKS-WLB; Syrek, Bauer-Emmel, Antoni & Klusemann, 2011). Five Items which are assessed on 6-point Likert scales.
4. Fragebogen zum Erleben von Intensität und Tätigkeitsspielraum in der Arbeit (FIT) (Richter, Hemman, Merboth, Fritz, Hansgen, & Rudolf, 2000). The questionnaire was developed for the orientation, personal analysis of health-related work requirements. The scale measured by 13 items which are answered on four-point Likert scales

Covariates: Sex, age and volunteering length

Hypotheses 1 and 3 will be tested with t-test. Hypotheses 2 will be tested by correlation analyses (Pearson correlation, two-tailed). We will also calculate partial correlations (controlled for sex, age, length and duration of volunteering).

q22.value: Only participants who meet the criteria for participation in the study will be includein the data analysis (see data collection procedures). For example, we will exclude people who are under 18.

q23.value: Only people who have answered at least all items from one scale are included.

attributes.title: Neurodynamics of affect from the fMRI emotional picture viewing task in the MIDUS Refresher neuroscience project
attributes.description: The Midlife in the United States study (MIDUS) is a longitudinal national study of adults in the United States that began in 1995. MIDUS consists of several projects, including Survey, Daily Diary, Cognitive, Biomarkers, and Neuroscience projects. The original MIDUS sample was assessed between 1995-1997 (MIDUS 1), again between 2004-2009 (MIDUS 2), and again starting in 2013 (data collection ongoing; MIDUS 3). To replenish the original sample, new participants were added to the protocol between 2011-2014 (MIDUS Refresher).   This OSF page is intended to serve as the basis for several projects relating to the MIDUS Refresher neuroscience project functional MRI data. We outline here the details of how MIDUS Refresher fMRI data were collected, cleaned, and processed by our group.   Parts of the MIDUS Refresher fMRI data have already been analyzed and some hypotheses have already been tested by others in our group and will be noted when relevant. A clear delineation of what hypotheses have been tested and which have yet to be tested will be included when necessary.

summary.value: see "MIDUSRef-MainProjectPreregistration.pdf" for a description of our MIDUS Ref fMRI processing pipeline through level 2 analyses. This pipeline will be the basis of future group level analyses, hypotheses for which will be pre-registered as separate branches.
